title: Authors and Citation
text: Darius Görgen. Author, maintainer. Om Prakash Bahandri. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Görgen D, Bahandri O (2022). mapme.biodiversity: Efficient monitoring global biodiversity areas. R package version 0.0.0.9000.
code: @Manual{,   title = {mapme.biodiversity: Efficient monitoring of global biodiversity areas},   author = {Darius Görgen and Om Prakash Bahandri},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000}, }

title: An R package for processing global biodiversity data
text: Biodiversity areas, especially primary forests provide multiple ecosystem services local population planet whole. rapid exapnsion human landuse natural ecosystems impacts global climate crisis put natural ecosystems global biodiversity threat. mapme.biodiversity package helps analyse number biodiversity related indicators biodiversity threats based freely available geodata-sources Global Forest Watch. supports computational efficient routines heavy parallelization cloud-infrastructures AWS AZURE using statistical programming language R. package allows analysis global biodiversity portfolios thousand millions AOIs normally possible dedicated plattforms Google Earth Engine. package plattform agnostic provides possibility e.g. analyze World Database Protected Areas (WDPA). primary use case package support scientific analysis data science individuals organizations seek preserve planets biodiversity. ’s development funded German Development Bank KfW. Important Note development currently work progress. Additional information published shortly.

what: WorldClim climatic variables (min temperature, max temperature, mean precipitation) — climate
title: WorldClim climatic variables (min temperature, max temperature, mean precipitation) — climate
text: resource published Fick et al. (2017) "WorldClim 2: new 1-km spatial resolution climate surfaces global land areas". resource represents multiple climatic variables requiring minimum temperature, maximum temperature, mean precipitation layers. layers available download period 2000 - 2018 monthly basis WorldClim.

title: WorldClim climatic variables (min temperature, max temperature, mean precipitation) — climate
text: Global raster layers available years 2000 2018.

title: WorldClim climatic variables (min temperature, max temperature, mean precipitation) — climate
text: https://www.worldclim.org/data/index.html

title: WorldClim climatic variables (min temperature, max temperature, mean precipitation) — climate
text: Enlisted different resources can reqested dedicated functions: tmin Encoded (°C), representing minimum temperature per output grid cell. tmax Encoded (°C), representing maximum temperature per output grid cell. prec Encoded (mm), representing mean precipitation per output grid cell.

what: Calculate elevation statistics based on SRTM data sets — .calc_dem
title: Calculate elevation statistics based on SRTM data sets — .calc_dem
text: Considering 30m resolution SRTM raster datasets users can specify statistics among mean, median standard deviation compute. Also, users can specify functions .e. zonal package terra, extract package terra, exactextract exactextractr desired.

title: Calculate elevation statistics based on SRTM data sets — .calc_dem
code: .calc_dem(   shp,   srtmdem,   engine = "zonal",   stats_elevation = "mean",   rundir = tempdir(),   verbose = TRUE,   todisk = FALSE,   ... )

title: Calculate elevation statistics based on SRTM data sets — .calc_dem
text: shp single polygon calculate elevation statistic srtmdem elevation raster resource SRTM engine preferred processing functions either one "zonal", "extract" "exactextract" character. rundir directory intermediate files written . verbose directory intermediate files written . todisk Logical indicating whether temporary raster files shall written disk ... additional arguments stats Function applied compute statistics polygons either one multiple inputs character "mean", "median" "sd".

title: Calculate elevation statistics based on SRTM data sets — .calc_dem
text: tibble

(2004) "Terrestrial Ecosystems World (TEOW) WWF-US (Olson)". depicts 867 terrestrial ecoregions around world classified 14 different terrestrial biomes forests, grasslands, deserts. polygons represent ecoregions, defined relatively large units land inland water sharing large majority biodiversity. datasets made available World Wildlife Fund (WWF) year 2001.

F., Ricketts, T. H., Kura, Y., Lamoreux, J. F., Wettengel, W. W., Hedao, P., Kassem, K. R. 2001. Terrestrial ecoregions world: new map life Earth. Bioscience 51(11):933-938.

what: Initialization of a biodiversity portfolio object — init_portfolio

text: function expects sf object first argument contains geometry type POLYGON MULTIPOLYGON. row object considered single asset portfolio biodiversity indicators calculated processing chain. preliminary checks conducted, e.g. CRS object EPSG:4326 otherwise transformed. portfolio wide parameters output directory downloaded data sets, temporal directory intermediate calculation number cores available indicator calculation can set user fine-control workflow. However, parameters also set sensible defaults thus can omitted portfolio initialization.

title: Initialization of a biodiversity portfolio object — init_portfolio

title: Initialization of a biodiversity portfolio object — init_portfolio
text: x sf object transformed portfolio years Numeric vector time frame analysis handed vector consecutive years outdir Character indicating directory resources written . directory exist, attempt create . output director equal temporary directory. Defaults current working directory. tmpdir Character vector directory used intermediate files. Defaults output tempdir(), e.g. current R session's temporal directory. custom file path exist, attempt create . equal output directory. cores integer value indicating number cores host machine available indicator calculation. defaults parallel::detectCores() - 1 cores, .e. one core less available cores. aria_bin character vector aria2c executable parallel downloads verbose Logical, defaults TRUE, indicating progress information printed.

what: Year of forest loss occurence — lossyear
title: Year of forest loss occurence — lossyear
text: resource part publication Hansen et al. (2013) "High-Resolution Global Maps 21st-Century Forest Cover Change". represents "Forest loss period 2000–2020, defined stand-replacement disturbance, change forest non-forest state. Encoded either 0 (loss) else value range 1–20, representing loss detected primarily year 2001–2020, respectively." Due changes satellites products used compilation tree loss product, results year 2011 afterwards directly comparable reprocessing finished. Users aware limitation, especially timeframe analysis spans two periods delimited year 2011.

title: Year of forest loss occurence — lossyear
text: global tiled raster resource available land areas.

title: Year of forest loss occurence — lossyear
text: https://data.globalforestwatch.org/documents/tree-cover-loss/explore

title: Year of forest loss occurence — lossyear

Townshend. 2013. “High-Resolution Global Maps 21st-Century Forest Cover Change.” Science 342 (15 November): 850–53.

title: Calculate precipitation statistics — precipitation
text: functions allows calculate precipitation statistics based CHIRPS rainfall estimates. Corresponding time-frame analysis portfolio, monthly precipitation statistics calculated. include total rainfall amount, rainfall anomaly 1981-2010 climate normal, Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) available scales 1 48 months. Th function needs SPEI package installed. required resources indicator : chirps

title: Calculate precipitation statistics — precipitation
text: tibble column years, months, absolute rainfall, rainfall anomaly one columns per selected time-scale SPI.

title: Calculate precipitation statistics — precipitation
text: following arguments can set: scales_spi integer vector indicating scales calculate SPI. engine preferred processing functions either one "zonal", "extract" "exactextract" character.

title: Soildgrids data layers — soilgrids
text: Soilgrids project combining global observation data machine learning map spatial distribution soil properties across globe. produced spatial resolution 250 meters parameters mapped different depths. order able assess prediction uncertainty, besides mean median prediction, 0.05 0.95 percentile predictions available. following parameters available: bdod Bulk density fine earth fraction (cg/cm3) cec Cation Exchange Capacity soil (mmol(c)/kg) cfvo Volumetric fraction coarse fragments > 2 mm (cm3/dm3 (volPerc)) clay Proportion clay particles < 0.002 mm fine earth fraction (g/kg) nitrogen Total nitrogen (cg/kg) phh2o Soil pH (pHx10) sand Proportion sand particles > 0.05 mm fine earth fraction (g/kg) silt Proportion silt particles >= 0.002 mm <= 0.05 mm fine earth fraction (g/kg) soc Soil organic carbon content fine earth fraction (dg/kg) ocd Organic carbon density (kg/m3) ocs Organic carbon stocks (t/ha)

title: Soildgrids data layers — soilgrids
text: global tiled raster resource available land areas.

title: Soildgrids data layers — soilgrids
text: https://www.isric.org/explore/soilgrids

title: Soildgrids data layers — soilgrids
text: Users can specify following arguments: layer soil parameter single charachter depth requested depth single chrachter stat predicted statistic single charachter Except ocs, available depth "0-30cm", parameters available following depths: "0-5cm" "5-15cm" "15-30cm" "30-60cm" "60-100cm" "100-200cm" parameter depth available following statistics: "Q0.05" "Q0.50" "mean" "Q0.95"

title: Soildgrids data layers — soilgrids
text: Hengl T, Mendes de Jesus J, Heuvelink GBM, Ruiperez Gonzalez M, Kilibarda M, et al. (2017) SoilGrids250m: Global gridded soil information based machine learning. PLOS ONE 12(2): e0169748. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0169748

title: Treecover for the year 2000 — treecover2000

Encoded percentage per output grid cell, range 0–100." Due changes satellites products used compilation treecover product, results year 2011 afterwards directly comparable reprocessing finished. what: Calculate Terrain Ruggedness Index (TRI) statistics — tri
title: Calculate Terrain Ruggedness Index (TRI) statistics — tri
text: Terrain Ruggedness Index measurement developed Riley, et al. (1999). elevation difference center pixel eight immediate pixels squared averaged square root taken get TRI value. function allows efficiently calculate terrain ruggedness index (tri) statistics polygons. polygon, desired statistic/s (mean, median sd) /returned. required resources indicator : srtmdem

title: Calculate Terrain Ruggedness Index (TRI) statistics — tri
text: tibble column terrain ruggedness index statistics (meters). range index values corresponding meaning: (1) 0 - 80 m  :- level surface (2) 81-116 m  :- nearly level surface (3) 117-161 m :- slightly rugged surface (4) 162-239 m :- intermediately rugged surface (5) 240-497 m :- moderately rugged surface (6) 498-958 m :- highly rugged surface (7) 959-4367 m:- extremely rugged surface

title: Calculate Terrain Ruggedness Index (TRI) statistics — tri
text: following arguments can set: stats Function applied compute statistics polygons either single multiple inputs character "mean", "median" "sd". engine preferred processing functions either one "zonal", "extract" "exactextract" character.
